Biosciences
Rationale
The suggested changes to the assessment are bringing the module in line with the new School of Life Sciences assessment guidelines. These guidelines were ratified by the Board of Studies in January 2017, after extensive consultation of all teaching staff (individual and programme teams) and students (individual and student representatives). These guidelines are based on the School’s Teaching Review 2016 which found that students are over-assessed and that the assessments in different modules and programmes are not consistent. Therefore, the new guidelines aim to reduce the overall assessment workload and to ensure fairness and consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting.
Blurb
Overview
This module studies the body plans of the major groups of animals and explores the relationship between body form and function.

It also discusses the evlolutionary origins of these basic body plans and how these have been modified to adapt to particular habitats.

The module will be taught through a mixture of asynchronous and synchronous material. The former consists of pre-recorded videos and other online learning material, the latter consists of scheduled interactive online sessions. Students will also be given guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module.

The module will be assessed through continuous assessment.
Educational Aims
To foster in students an u nderstanding of structure and function of the basic body plan of the major groups of animals;

​To encourage the a ppreciation of the evolutionary origins of the basic body plan of animals;

​To develop an u nderstanding of how the basic body plan of animals has been modified to adapt to different modes of existence and habitats;

To develop  knowledge and understanding in animal biodiversity, and the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve problems in zoology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module studies the body plans of the major groups of animals and explores the relationship between body form and function.

It also discusses the evlolutionary origins of these basic body plans and how these have been modified to adapt to particular habitats.

The module will be taught through a mixture of asynchronous and synchronous material. The former consists of pre-recorded videos and other online learning material, the latter consists of scheduled interactive online sessions. Students will also be given guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module.

The module will be assessed through continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
This module addresses the major animal taxa, their characteristics, origins, fossil records (where available) and phylogenetic relationships. The relationship between form and function and the factors that shape them will be explored. Specifically, for each of the taxa, the basic life functions (nutrition, respiration, circulation, sensory functions, locomotion, egestion, excretion, reproduction and growth) will be described to link the phylogenetic relationships with animal structure.

The tree of life;

Protists and sponges;

Cnidaria;

Flatworms;

Roundworms;

Real worms;

Arthropods;

Echinoderms;

Minor phyla;

Early chordates;

Fish;

Reptiles;

Birds;

Amphibians;

Mammals;

Primates;

Humans.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to asynchronous pre-recorded videos delivering the content of the module (appr. 2 hours per week)
Attendance Recorded: No

Teaching Method 2: Online seminars
Description: This refers to weekly synchronous (timetabled) online interactive seminars to consolidate student learning (appr. 1 hour per week)
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Self directed learning in this module refers to directed reading, preparation for assessment, and completion of formative assessment exercises.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 will be an online test midway through the semester.

Assessment 2 will be an online test at the end of the semester.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO3 ​ To ​read and interpret phylogenetic trees

To foster in students an u nderstanding of structure and function of the basic body plan of the major groups of animals;

​To encourage the a ppreciation of the evolutionary origins of the basic body plan of animals;

​To develop an u nderstanding of how the basic body plan of animals has been modified to adapt to different modes of existence and habitats;

To develop  knowledge and understanding in animal biodiversity, and the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve problems in zoology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module studies the body plans of the major groups of animals and explores the relationship between body form and function.

It also discusses the evlolutionary origins of these basic body plans and how these have been modified to adapt to particular habitats.

The module will be taught through a mixture of asynchronous and synchronous material. The former consists of pre-recorded videos and other online learning material, the latter consists of scheduled interactive online sessions. Students will also be given guided reading, and regular formative assessment exercises will enable students to evaluate their understanding of the module.

The module will be assessed through continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
This module addresses the major animal taxa, their characteristics, origins, fossil records (where available) and phylogenetic relationships. The relationship between form and function and the factors that shape them will be explored. Specifically, for each of the taxa, the basic life functions (nutrition, respiration, circulation, sensory functions, locomotion, egestion, excretion, reproduction and growth) will be described to link the phylogenetic relationships with animal structure.

The tree of life;

Protists and sponges;

Cnidaria;

Flatworms;

Roundworms;

Real worms;

Arthropods;

Echinoderms;

Minor phyla;

Early chordates;

Fish;

Reptiles;

Birds;

Amphibians;

Mammals;

Primates;

Humans.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to asynchronous pre-recorded videos delivering the content of the module (appr. 2 hours per week)
Attendance Recorded: No

Teaching Method 2: Online seminars
Description: This refers to weekly synchronous (timetabled) online interactive seminars to consolidate student learning (appr. 1 hour per week)
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Self directed learning in this module refers to directed reading, preparation for assessment, and completion of formative assessment exercises.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 will be an online test midway through the semester.

Assessment 2 will be an online test at the end of the semester.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Rationale
The suggested changes to the assessment are bringing the module in line with the new School of Life Sciences assessment guidelines. These guidelines were ratified by the Board of Studies in January 2017, after extensive consultation of all teaching staff (individual and programme teams) and students (individual and student representatives). These guidelines are based on the School’s Teaching Review 2016 which found that students are over-assessed and that the assessments in different modules and programmes are not consistent. Therefore, the new guidelines aim to reduce the overall assessment workload and to ensure fairness and consistency in the School’s assessment format and weighting.
